name: Split
fun_fact: Fun fact: Split's most traditional cooking method, peka, involves burying a heavy iron dish under hot coals for up to 4 hours - and locals say the best peka is still cooked the old way in fireplaces, not modern ovens, giving the meat a distinctive smoky flavor impossible to replicate.

hero_dishes.name: Pa코ticada
hero_dishes.description: Slow-cooked beef in a rich, sweet-savory sauce made with pro코ek (sweet wine), prunes, nutmeg, and onions. Usually served with homemade gnocchi.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Dalmatian culinary magic that takes two days to prepare - the beef marinates overnight, then simmers for hours until fork-tender. Each family guards their own secret recipe passed down through generations. It's the dish that defines Dalmatian sophistication.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Konoba Hvaranin (traditional preparation, cozy family atmosphere), Mala Kate (huge portions at local prices), 맛g Restaurant (modern interpretation, Michelin Bib Gourmand)

hero_dishes.name: Peka (Octopus, Veal, or Lamb)
hero_dishes.description: Meat and vegetables slow-cooked under a bell-shaped iron lid buried in hot coals for 3-4 hours. The meat becomes incredibly tender while potatoes absorb all the juices.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A traditional Dalmatian method dating back centuries when shepherds and fishermen cooked outdoors. The peka (iron dome) creates a sealed environment where meat steams in its own juices. Octopus peka is the coastal specialty, while inland areas favor veal or lamb.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Must be ordered 24 hours in advance at traditional konobas (taverns) throughout Split

hero_dishes.name: Crni Ri쬺t (Black Risotto)
hero_dishes.description: Creamy risotto made with cuttlefish or squid and their ink, giving it a dramatic black color and briny, oceanic flavor.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Dalmatian coast classic that showcases the Adriatic's cuttlefish. The ink not only colors the dish but adds a subtle seafood sweetness. It's available at almost every restaurant in Split - finding bad black risotto is actually hard.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Available throughout Split, particularly good at Konoba Fetivi (Michelin-recognized), Villa Spiza (artfully prepared)

hero_dishes.name: Buzara (Mussels or Scampi)
hero_dishes.description: Adriatic seafood cooked in olive oil, white wine, garlic, and fresh herbs. Served 'na bijelo' (white sauce) or 'na crveno' (red sauce with tomato).
hero_dishes.origin_story: A traditional Dalmatian cooking method that lets fresh seafood shine. The aromatic sauce is perfect for soaking up with crusty bread. Using same-day caught Adriatic shellfish makes all the difference.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Konoba Fetivi, coastal restaurants along Split's harbor, Villa Spiza

signature_drinks.name: Pro코ek
signature_drinks.description: Traditional Dalmatian dessert wine made from dried grapes, sweet and aromatic with notes of dried fruit and honey.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served after meals with dessert or cheese. Used in cooking (especially pa코ticada). Locals treasure family recipes passed down for generations.

signature_drinks.name: Rakija
signature_drinks.description: Croatian fruit brandy, often made from grapes (loza), plums, or figs. Clear, strong (40%+ alcohol), and traditional.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The ultimate digestive, drunk after heavy meals. Locals often make their own, and offering homemade rakija is a sign of hospitality. Served room temperature in small glasses.

food_culture_notes: Marenda (Croatian soul food brunch) is served at konohas from 10:30am to 2pm - traditional local dishes at their most authentic
Dinner doesn't start before 7-8pm, even later in summer when it's too hot to eat earlier
Reservations are essential at popular spots like Konoba Fetivi - locals book days in advance
Fresh grilled fish is always served with blitva (boiled potatoes and swiss chard) - it's the mandatory Dalmatian side dish
